summary: An email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney to defense attorney Roy Black regarding the case Jane Doe v. United States, concerning Jeffrey Epstein. The email discusses an upcoming status conference before Judge Marra and the potential need to turn over an agreement.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Addressee of the email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the case Jane Doe v. United States and Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Judge Marra
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case Jane Doe v. United States; the email anticipates he may order the parties to turn over an agreement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named in the subject line of the email, indicating the correspondence relates to legal matters involving him.

connections.description: Roy Black is a defense attorney being contacted regarding the case involving Jeffrey Epstein, strongly suggesting a legal representation relationship.
The Assistant U.S. Attorney is corresponding with defense attorney Roy Black regarding an upcoming court proceeding.
Judge Marra is presiding over the case in which Roy Black is involved as an attorney.

events.title: Status Conference in Jane Doe v. United States
events.description: A status conference scheduled by Judge Marra for the case Jane Doe v. United States, concerning Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: The email is dated August 13, 2008, and discusses an urgent need to resolve an issue regarding turning over an agreement in the case Jane Doe v. United States.
The correspondence involves Assistant U.S. Attorney Roy Black and references Judge Marra, indicating active federal litigation related to Jeffrey Epstein in 2008.
The subject matter suggests the existence of a confidential or non-public agreement that may be subject to court-ordered disclosure.
